p: Proposed therapeutic interventions. The current therapeutic interventions for COVID-19 ( 18) are derived from SARS treatments; the first drugs shown in 2005 to be effective in vitro for SARS, both pre- and post-exposure, are chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine; since they were extensively studied and shown to exert pleiotropic antiviral actions ( 58). Chloroquine is a weakly basic substance and upon entering cells it is protonated and concentrated in acidic organelles: lysosomes, Golgi vesicles and endosomes; the subsequent increase in endosomal pH interferes with the terminal glycosilation of the ACE2 receptor. Besides inhibiting the S protein-induced viral fusion ( 59), and the PlPro protease ( 60) chloroquine can benefit patients with porphirin extravasation ( Fig. 2) by preventing orf1ab, orf3a, orf10 attack on hemoglobin ( 37) with porphirin formation.
